Posts.Content: My husband did chemo and hormone therapy prior to surgery. Before treatment, he had many many tumors throughout abdomen area and 3 positive lymph nodes. In fact, one tumor was so close to the rectum, that his surgery would have been cancelled if chemo didn't work. Thankfully, chemo worked. I will never forget the day when doctors told us surgery was a go because of the chemo and hormone therapy. The path report after surgery showed 2 nodes positive. Danny's cancer is ductual prostate cancer that is aggressive and rare. It's been 3 years since his surgery and still cancer free. There isn't much info on patients 5 years after diagnosis and our oncologist is pleasantly surprised that cancer hasn't come back yet. We went in with faith and hope but no promises.....Never give up!!!!!
Posts.Signature: Husband was 70 yrs old when diagnosed in Jan 2013 with ductal prostate cancer that invaded the bladder, urethra, part of right ureter, and lymph nodes. Gleason 4+5=9 Highest PSA was 8.4 Received chemo drugs Cabazitaxel and Carboplation as well as shots of Degarelix and Lupron for about 4 months total. Had his prostate, bladder, testicles, and lymph nodes removed June 2013. Has been cancer free since
Posts.Title: Progressive Cancer after Chemo....

Posts.Content: He had a prostate biopsy a couple of years ago and it came back negative. The CT Scan he had done on Mon showed just a big black mass over the whole area. When the urologist tried to go in and look with the scope, he couldn't go very far in the uretha because of the tumors, and the dr said he couldn't find any landmarks as he was looking. My husband is 70 next Tues and I think his last PSA was 5 or 6?

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> My husband is 70 next Tues and I think

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with cancer

Posts.Content: My husband was told two days ago that he has cancer, either of the prostate or bladder. The urologist did a cystoscopy in the office, but could not go as far as he wanted because of all the tumors in the uretha. He said the prostate was hard on one side but not very enlarged...since 2011, he's been treated for BPH by another urologist. The doctor said that if he had to bet, he'd go with prostate. My husband is suppose to go next week for another cystoscopy, but this time it will be done at the hospital. Right now, we're looking at options of going to a bigger hospital, we live in a very small town. From what we can understand, it's spreading whether it's bladder or prostate cancer. We are just beginning this process. We've both dealt with cancer involving other family members are are aware that moving cancer is not good at all. We are looking at John Hopkins, MD Anderson, or Duke. Any advise would be greatly appreciated. Thank you for your time.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks for the replies. We are currently being seen at Duke, that's where the biopsies were taken. We meet with the oncologist on the 4th, guess we'll know more then. We're also looking at going to MD Anderson or Johns Hopkins for second opinion. At least now we know what we're are dealing with, the waiting was nerve racking.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with cancer

Posts.Content: We got pathology report... A. Prostatic Urethral Tumor, biopsy: Prostatic Adenocarcinoma, consistent with ductal variant, involving essentiall 100% of the specimen. B. Bladder mass, transurethral resection of tumor: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, gleason patter 4+4=8, consistent with ductal variant, involving approximately 80-90% of the specimen. This part has a long comment C. Urethral Lesion, Biopsy: Prostatic adenocarcinomna, gleason pattern 4+4=8, consistent with ductal variant, involving 15% of the specimen. All the PA told us was that this is an aggressive prostate cancer. Have appt on the 30th to remove stents. Can anyone give me an idea what all this means?

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks Chuck for the Google searches....you're right, I've seen most of these, but thanks for your help. The medical oncologist said he does not treat this with hormones to shrink the tumors prior to surgery, he recommended what the surgeon said...take out prostate, bladder, and lymph nodes. MD Anderson is suppose to be calling us tomorrow for an appointment, we've waited a week now. Even though Duke seems to be a good place, and say they've treated this kind of prostate cancer, we really want to talk to MD Anderson before we do anything major.
Posts.Title: Ductal prostate cancer

Posts.Content: My husband has ductal prostate cancer that has invaded the bladder, urethra, and possibly the surrounding lymph nodes. We're waiting on PET Scan on Wed to find out if it's anywhere else. Right now the only option we have is removing the bladder, prostate, and lymph nodes. Does anybody else have this rare type of cancer? Any advice will be greatly appreciated.
Posts.Title: Ductal prostate cancer

Posts.Content: I've googled it extensively, but can only find a few article. Was hoping that someone here might have had experience with the one. Age 70 Gleason Score 4+4=8 PSA 8.37

Posts.Title: Ductal prostate cancer

Posts.Content: It comes from the prostatic ducts and accounts for about 1% of PC. It's already spread to the bladder and urethra. We've seen the surgeon who did the biopsies and the medical oncologist. Both recommend removing the bladder, prostate, and surrounding lymph nodes. PET Scan and radiation oncologist appointments are next week. Everything I've read deals with regular PC. Thank you for your replies.
Posts.Title: Ductal prostate cancer

Posts.Title: Ductal prostate cancer

Posts.Content: I've googled it extensively, but can only find a few article. Was hoping that someone here might have had experience with the one. Age 70 Gleason Score 4+4=8 PSA 8.37
Posts.Title: Ductal prostate cancer

Posts.Content: My husband is on chemo for ductal prostate cancer. He goes for the third round on 4-9. This second round is really kicking his butt as he's extremely fatigued and weak. The doctor said that if the chemo was working, my husband would feel it because he would be able to urinate better and the pain level would decrease. Pain level is increasing every day. Wondering if this is because the chemo is not working? We see oncologist and surgeon next month. If tumors have not shrunk, surgeon is leery of doing the surgery. What scares me is that would mean this chemo not working and we don't have a plan B.
Posts.Title: Chemo working?

Posts.Content: I forgot to mention that he has ureter stents since they took the biopsies in Jan. Some of the back pain is caused from that as well as degeneration and arthritis. But he has a lot of burning type pain that goes through the penis and into the stomach area. When the pain is really bad, it's abdominal.
Posts.Title: Chemo working?

Posts.Content: Thank you for the replies. He is being treated at MD Anderson in Houston. There are one of a few that have experience with ductal. The cancer has spread to the bladder, urethra, and ureter. PET Scan in Jan didn't show any other advancement. Plan A is chemo then surgery to remove prostate, bladder, lymph nodes. Hopefully they will be able to get negative margins in the urethra and ureter. There is also concern that it's extremely close to the rectum as well; hasn't invaded yet, just close. We really didn't discuss what we would do if the tumors didn't shrink, guess we'll find out next month when we head back to Texas. The two chem meds are Cabazitaxel and Carboplatin. The first hormone shot was Degarelix and the last one was Lupron. It seems like his pain level is getting worse everyday instead of decreasing and there's nothing I can do to help....frustrating and infuriating.
Posts.Title: Chemo working?

Posts.Content: My husband and I received good news last week at our appointment at MD Anderson. Scans show that the chemo is shrinking the tumors, especially the ones in the lymph nodes. AND cancer has not spread to any other organs. Which meant they were able to take the ureter stents out without having to go the OR. He had a round of chemo while we were there, and scheduled for another in three weeks, here at home. We're going back next month, and hopefully they will be able to schedule his surgery. After 4 months of bad news, pain, and waiting, we finally got great news. Scary that the great news is that it's looking like he will still be able to have his prostate and bladder removed. He's scheduled for and endorectal MRI next month. We're praying that this will show that the tumor has moved away from the rectum as well. One day at a time...one day at a time.
Posts.Signature: Husband was 70 yrs old when diagnosed in Jan 2013 with ductal prostate cancer that invaded the bladder, urethra, part of right ureter, and lymph nodes. Gleason 4+5=9 Highest PSA was 8.4 Received chemo drugs Cabazitaxel and Carboplation as well as shots of Degarelix and Lupron for about 4 months total. Had his prostate, bladder, testicles, and lymph nodes removed June 2013. Has been cancer free since
Posts.Title: Good news

Posts.Content: Haven't been here for a while. I've recently searched the internet again for new info on ductual prostate cancer, but haven't found any. My husband has been cancer free since his surgery in 2013; however this year, he's been battling a couple of serious infections including nasty UTI pseudomonas and bowel infection C Diff. The C Diff one will not go away...he's been fighting this one off and on since Nov. I know the infections have taken a toll on him, but it seems like he's getting more fatigued every day, as well as more nauseated. We head back to M D Anderson for usual tests. Unfortunately, the infections disease dr that's handling his case will be out of town. They said the cancer would eventually come back and I still can't find info past 5 years, and that's the most frustrating part. Is there any one else out there who has info on this kind of cancer.
Posts.Signature: Husband was 70 yrs old when diagnosed in Jan 2013 with ductal prostate cancer that invaded the bladder, urethra, part of right ureter, and lymph nodes. Had his prostate, bladder, testicles, and lymph nodes removed June 2013. Has been cancer free since
Posts.Title: Ductual prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks Highlander for the links.... Micheal, he has urostomy bag, so no cath. They think the preventative antibiotics he was on for UTI is what caused the C Diff in the first place. He spend 11 days in hospital and they were able to get negative stool tests for the C Diff. And he was since tested positive as well as negative. The next time he tests positive, our doctor is going to get us into a doctor at Methodist Hospital(right next to MDA) who is doing fecal transplants with great results for people with C Diff. But without a positive test, he isn't eligible for the study...so we're waiting for the next positive test. Infectious Disease department was called in because of the nature of the problem as well as being able to regulate the antibiotics better. In fact the gastro dr at MDA is letting ID handle the case...the ID doctor is more knowledgeable about this than the gastro. I guess I'm worried that the cancer has spread and that's whats causing the problems. Apparently, ductual will metastasize to organs before it does bones, and he had a lot of tumors in and around the abdomen so the scare is always there. We'll find out next week, but still....can't help worrying.

Posts.Content: Been taking probiotics, but not really helping. Without the transplant, I don't think he can take that much probiotics.
